Experimental  Section  1.1 Chemicals   All chemicals and solvents were used without further purification. (1 R,2R)-Boc-1,2-diaminocyclohexane (RcHDAm -Boc, 98%, DAICEL), (1 S,2S)-Boc- 1,2-diaminocyclohexane (ScHDAm -Boc, 98%, DAICEL), Pyromellitic dianhydride (BDA, 98%, Innochem),  Tris(4 -formylphenyl)amine (TPA, 98%, TENSUS BIOTECH), Cyclohexylamine (cHex -Am, Enerey Chemical), Tris(pentafluorophenyl)borane ( TFPB, 98%, Enerey Chemical), Sodium chloride (NaCl, 99.5%, Innochem), trifluoroacetic acid (TFA, 99%, Innochem), Dichloromethane (  DCM, AR, Innochem), Milli- Q water (H 2O, 18.2 M ¦¸¡¤cm), n-Hexane (Hex, AR, Innochem) 1,2-Dichloroethane( DCE, AR, Enerey Chemical),  N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF, AR, Innochem), Ethyl acetate (EA, AR, Concord Technology), Toluene (Tol, AR, Concord Technology), Methanol (MeOH, AR, Concord Technology).

S2 RBDI-Boc:  Pyromellitic dianhydride ( BDA , 20 mmol , 4.36 g)  and ( 1R,2R)-Boc- 1,2-cyclohexanediamine (RcHDAm -Boc, 42 mmol , 9 g ) were dissolved in 100 mL  N,N- dimethyl-formamide (DMF) in a 250 mL flask , which was exchanged by dry nitrogen gas for three times  and allowed react ion at 100¡ãC under the nitrogen atmosphere for about 12 h. After cooling to the room temperature , the reaction solution was slowly poured into sodium chloride saturated acid ic water  (pH = 5-6). Then, the generated  precipitates  were  filter ed with suction  and wash ed with ionized water for 3 times till the filtate turn to  neutral , which were further dried to obtain white powder as the target product RBDI-Boc (68%).

S3 RBDI¡¤TFA: As shown in Scheme S2, RBDI-Boc was dissolved in 100 mL  DCM in a 250 mL flask,  which  was stirred at room temperature for 20  mim. During this process, a n excess amount of trifluoroacetic acid  (~ 20 mL) was slowly added to make the solution clear , which  was further stirred at room temperature for 12 h. The n, DCM  was removed under reduced pressure  and a small amount of methanol (~ 5 mL) was added to the mixture, which was treated by ultrasonica tion. After that, dispersion  was filtered and washed with about  5 mL methanol to obtain  white powder  (75%) .

RHC: As shown in Scheme S 3, TPA (0.658 g, 2 mmol) and RBDI¡¤TFA (3.63 g, 6 mmol) were dissolved in 10 0 mL  DCM in a 250 mL flask . The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 3  days. After the reaction, the dichloromethane was removed by rotating evaporation . The residuals S4 were filtered and  washed several times with the mixed solvents of DCM and methanol. Then, the solids were recrystallized in DCM and methanol to get light yellow powders as the target product RHC (60%) .

TPA -cHex : As shown in Scheme S4, TPA (658 mg, 2 mmol) and cHex -Am (793 mg, 8 mmol) were dissolved in 60 mL  tetrahydrofuran (THF) in a 100 mL flask. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24h. After the reaction, tetrahydrofuran  was removed by rotating evaporation. Then, the solids were recrystallized in DCM and methanol.  Finally, faint yellow powders was obtained (66%).

2. Preparation of Aggregat ion Sample s  HC & TFPB/ HC: 17.82 mg of RHC (or SHC) powder was  dissolved in 2 mL of toluene  (Tol, solvent)  under heating and ultrasonication  as solution A . 51.1 mg of TFPB was dissolved  in 5 mL of toluene under heating and ultrasonication as solution B. The slution A and B were cooled naturally down to room temperature and mixed to form TFPB/HC  complex solutions with different molar ratios ( 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 , the total volume is kept at 400 ¦ÌL). For the samples of TFPB/HC  = 5, 6, 8, 10, the required amount s of TFPB were disscolved into  200 uL toluene, which were added into  200 ¦ÌL of solution A to prepare TFPB/HC  complex solutions. The total volume is also kept at 400 ¦Ì L. After that, a volume of  1600 uL n- hexane  (Hex, antisolvent) was added into each solution and shake d quickly , which were left s tand overnight for test s. All samples were stored away from light.

3. Preparation of Single Crystal s  RHC: 17.82 mg RHC powder was dissolved into 2 mL dichloromethane  (DCM), which was  filtered using 0.22 ¦Ì m filters to give a clear solution  (1¡Á10-4 M). Then , 1 mL N, N -dimethylformamide (DMF) was injected slowly with a syringe and a small amount of DCM was added  to prevent rapid precipitation. After slow evaporation, the light yellow flake crystals RHC were  obtained.

TFPB/SHC: The 1, 2 -dichloroethane (DCE) solution of TFPB/SHC with a molar ratio of 4 was prepared  and filtered using 0.22 ¦Ì m filters to give a clear solution  (1¡Á10-4 M). Then, a small amount of DCM was added  to prevent rapid precipitation. After slow evaporation  for 3 ~ 5 days , light yellow flake crystals  were obtained.   S7 4. Preparation of NMR Samples  (1) Temperature -dependent 1H NMR : RHC was dissolved into  chloroform -d (CDCl 3) with the concentration of 1¡Á10-4 M. Then, the temperature- dependent 1H NMR  was performed from 323 K to 223 K with an interval of 25 K .

¡öRESULTS AND DISCUSSIONSynthesis and Characterization ofthe Helical Cages(HCs). Pyromellitic dianhydride (BDA) was first covalentlymodified with two chiral cyclohexanediamine (R/ScHDAm) toproduce pyromellitic diimide (R/SBDI) astheedge (Figures S1and S2), and tris(4-formylphenyl)amine (TPA) was selected asthe facet, which were linked together bydynamic covalentimine bonds4toconstructR/SHC (Figure 1aand Schemes S1?S3inthe Supporting Information). Due tothe high directionrole ofintrinsically chiral V-shapedR/ScHDAm and thedynamic reactivity ofimine bonds,R/SHC were obtained athigh isolated yields (>60%) incomparison with most covalentmolecular cages. Only one molecular ionpeak was detected at1782.74138 m/z (M +H) in high-resolution massspectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS, Figures 1b, S3, and S4),confirming adiscrete [3+2]-type molecular cage structure withthreeR/SBDI and two TPA moieties.1HNMR spectroscopyfurther showed that allofthe formyl groups were convertedinto the imine bonds, and allofthe protons onR/SBDI andFigure1.Molecular design, synthesis, and characterizations. (a)Helical cages (HC) aresynthesized through dynamic imine chemistry. (b) High-resolution MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry confirms a[3+2]-type molecular structure. (c)1HNMR spectra ofRHC compared with itsprecursorsRBDI and TPA (asterisk denotes theresidual protons ofCDCl3).(d,e)Single-crystal structure ofRHC hasahelical and concave conformation withadihedral angle of¡ÏABB¡äA¡ä =60¡ã and acenter distance of4.937 ?between two nitrogen atoms ofTPA facets, much smaller than thelength ofBDI edges (9.642 ?,thedistance between two chiral carbon atoms directly linked tothesame BDI).RHC displays aglobal M-helicity forboth TPAand BDI units, while TPA propellers also have alocalP-helicity.Journal oftheAmerican Chemical Society pubs.acs.org/JACS Articlehttps://doi.org/10.1021/jacs.3c09461J.Am.Chem.Soc.2023,145,27639?2764927640TPA were inone setofchemical shifts (Figures 1c,S5, andS6), evidencing ahighly symmetric chemical environment.
